text:
Yeah, they are trying to make it look like lack of access is the reason why they can’t stop attacks, but only nuts would believe that.
So pointless. ISIS has insane amounts of money and tons of operatives from all fields. What would stop them from having someone develop a secure chat app for them only? absolutely nothing. Also, they will still meet in person, in closed apartments, in public places and one can’t do anything about that except arrest them - and mostly release them, like they did with that dude from paris.
basically banning mathematics
pssst don’t mention that to twitter, everyone would vote for it :joy::joy:
send math..underground
differentials in dark alleys
<@U08MQ0F8V|amal> has joined the channel
<@U0JBVPQUT|katlo> has joined the channel
<@U0JBE5N6A|geofflane> has joined the channel
Hey everyone! Let's get this thing going. Welcome to our first policy chat. Joining us to talk about all things DSM is <@U0DQYPAGZ>.
Welcome, <@U0DQYPAGZ>. I think the first question for a lot of people is what is DSM and why should Android devs care?
Hi everyone, it's a pleasure to be here and to meet you all

Good questions, DSM is keeping us very busy. As you said Peter, DSM is a move to eliminate barriers within the EU for digital goods and services. The European Union wants to create an online market where there is no fragmentation or barriers that cause the differences in supplying and enjoying products (different prices when buying online, difficoult VAT system…).
The Digital Single Market strategy will make this real through the adoption of different rules, proposed throughout the year 2016
Here I am waiting to buy stuff on <http://Amazon.com|Amazon.com>.
Ah ! Hi Andreas, good to talk to you
Hey <@U0DQYPAGZ> ! Since the DSM public consultations are over, is there a way we can get some influence over the laws now?
Hi Bluecup, some of the consultations are over, you're right, but some others are coming up
and of course there's a way to make your voice heard, through us

The Apps Alliance most important goal is advocate on your behalf, represent developers in policy debates and make sure that the interest of startuppers and digital SMEs are clear and well communicated.
We responded to the consultation on Online Platforms, and will organise an event on the same topic on 15th March at the European Parliament
This is one of the many ways to influence the European Decision Making process.
I can go on and on - happy to get more questions about this!
Has there been anything about who exactly will be in the European Data Protection Board that will create Data Protection regulations and what will those regulations be based on?
It all seems pretty generic from this POV and like nothing has been defined :confused:
Good question ! So, all of this is in the new General Data Protection Regulations, which refines a little bit the old names and structures

It will be highly interesting to see the strengthening of customer rights (which is a good thing) balanced against the business side of things, especially for startups, SMEs and even individual developers. If I imagine the brick and mortar store customer rights applied to digital goods, this can get messy for small devs pretty fast and push them out of the market even if it comes to extreme cases. This worries me a bit. (Also hi <@U0DQYPAGZ> :wave: )
[Not to all: go ahead and drop in questions and comments as they occur to you and we can circle back to them later. Slack is asynchronous! :oldtimeparrot:]

the European Data Protection Board is just the new name given to the Article 29 Working Party. It will still be an advisory board which will give interpretation of the rules and participate in possible trans-national cases of law infringement
It won't actually make any law, will just help us understand how to apply the existing ones
^^^So how does that work? Like, what does it mean for <@U061HDV96>, who needs a red bull, BTW
Hi Langerhans, great to see you here! I know, business and consumers sides can look slightly unbalanced, and I'll be happy to talk more about purchases of digital goods
Hello <@U0DQYPAGZ>, what’s the current stance on VAT in different EU countries and unified pricing?
is there anything that worries you ?

Many small developers store their customer info/data that is stored on 3rd party services (Amazon/Parse etc) where that data isn't necessarily physically stored within the EU. How would these rules apply and are there any guidelines to the developer as to what they are liable for?
I know Data Protection was a good start. So
Oh I misread the DSM explanation. I thought it was to remove the barriers globally. That <http://amazon.com|amazon.com> comment came out of nowhere then.
<@U061HDV96>:  actually it’s pretty valid, since for example even here in Croatia, a member state of EU, we can’t order a lot of things from any amazon, including .de that others can.

just looking for the current stance on it in the working party - is the pricing going to be determined before VAT and people in different places will see different final prices? Or is it moving into a “cyber-VAT” for e-products that is standardised across EU
Data Protection Board: whenever there is a case which interests data subject based in different countries, and it is not clear what national authority is competent, the board takes decisions
when it comes to VAT, since 1st december the new VAT rules entered into force
and now what counts is the place of supply
<@U0DQYPAGZ>: what new VAT rules? I have no idea what is going on.
Another question - currency exchange. euros, pounds, kroner, kunas, etc.. who will pay the exchange fees - the consumer or the producer/merchant?
this counts for indie developers, because for those apps available on app stores, these will be taking care of VAT
is this your case <@U053PPGDC>?
no I work for a corporation just curious

Hi <@U04U5KS3Z> , those developers storing data on 3rd parties service don't have to worry about data tranfers. Amazon has backup rules that allow the company to store data outside the EU in a lawful way! What interest you as well?
<@U0548MM6B>: I totally see your comments, that issue is discussed when it comes to e-commerce, parcel delivery, and it is the first concern for EU institutions
Aren't those trans-national portability problems earthed in private-hold licensing issues rather than a matter of copyright enforcement? I do not understand how the EU can impact that.
<@U061HDV96>: have you read anything about the new VAT regime from last here? we wrote an awesome blog on the Apps Alliance page, let me send you the link
<http://www.appdevelopersalliance.org/news/eu-value-added-tax-vat-changes-what-you-need-to-know>

attachments.title: EU Value-Added Tax (VAT) Changes - What You Need to Know
attachments.text: Startups and small businesses who sell digital goods in Europe are gearing up for a major change coming in the new year. Despite outcry from these business owners, new EU VAT, or value-added tax, regulations are set to go into effect on January 1st, 2015.
attachments.fallback: Application Developers Alliance: EU Value-Added Tax (VAT) Changes - What You Need to Know

text: <@U0DQYPAGZ>: no. I haven't had any time because of finals and other stuff. Thank you for the link.

attachments.title: EU Value-Added Tax (VAT) Changes - What You Need to Know
attachments.text: Startups and small businesses who sell digital goods in Europe are gearing up for a major change coming in the new year. Despite outcry from these business owners, new EU VAT, or value-added tax, regulations are set to go into effect on January 1st, 2015.
attachments.fallback: Application Developers Alliance: EU Value-Added Tax (VAT) Changes - What You Need to Know

text: <@U053PPGDC|zmarkan> pinned a message to this channel.

yay :tada: 
With coming of DSM, will access to Digital services like Spotify, which is ironically based in Sweden, be open to every member state or will they still retain rights to block certain states due to license and copyright holding conflicts?
<@U0F3B7CU9>: awesome question, copyright is of course territorial, but geoblocking is the number one fight of Commissioner Ansip
Extending on that, can I block my app from being sold in certain member states for arbitrary reasons?
the compromise is going to be working on territorial licensing (on short and long term), and then acting on geo-blocking
it is actually true that it will be possible to watch Netflix all over Europe while travelling :simple_smile:
The Commission just released the proposal on elimination of geo-blocking in December, and have a looong comprehensive strategy aimed at reorming copyright

The rules of geo-blocking work this way: from 2017 (hopefully), everyone will be able to have access to Spotify, netflix and other from wherever they are, if the service was available in the country of origin in the first place.

yes, and I wonder about the leverage here. I think about streaming, i.e. rai is the Italian TV dominator and they broadcast it to the net as well, but without an Italian proxy, no way. How can the EU apply pressure on an inherently corrupt and eroded country like Italy?

This is actually a sector under evaluation. For the time being, acting on digital services might be easier, because technology allows that. For televisions, the Commission just closed different consultations, will come up with results in the upcoming months and with a proposal by the end of 2016
there are different interests to be heard and represented when discussing these issues, but be sure that Commissioner Ansip is committed to succed

That’s great news :simple_smile:
The part of DSM that touches upon Data collection worries me, if we as developers use analytics and that is considered non-personal information, it is anonymised and detached from the user, but now the user will have the right to download and transfer personal and non-personal information, that will make our job difficult and user’s information vulnerable.Will that kind of data be excluded from non-personal information and what will be the border that defines what the user can download and what he can’t?
I am sure that this is a concern!
so, the right to access and the right to data portability concern just personal data that is being processes in a structured way. It has to be elaborated in a commonly used and interoperable format
So when it is made law, how long does everyone have to change their systems?

There is a certain level of uncertainty around anonymised data, because it is not mentioned in the regulation. It is pseudonymised data then! I'll be more than happy to look into that and get back to you <@U0548MM6B>
thanks <@U0DQYPAGZ>
<@U061HDV96>: two years after the adoption, luckily legislators will give some time to business to comply
So in 2019, realistically 2020. *sigh*

> It has to be elaborated in a commonly used and interoperable format
What happens if the user can’t upload data from service #1 to service #2? Does any of those get a fine or something?
<@U061HDV96>: just about when lunchbreak becomes a unicorn :wink:
<@U0548MM6B>: because you'll order a sandwich from Russia for when you're in Belgium.
<@U0548MM6B>: too bad, but yes, the law foresees fines if the rules are not respected
those depends on the company annual turnover
Are the legislators aware of how fast tech moves and that many of the rules they're setting out now may not necessarily be appropriate by the time the legislation comes in to effect?
<@U0DQYPAGZ>: so I get fine for not supporting a format that is possibly “common”  (wondering what that will define) like XML or if our companies have different data structures so it can’t upload?

We are telling them this in any possible way <@U04U5KS3Z>, sometimes they tend to forget :simple_smile:. And for us is necessary to make clear that SMEs and startuppers eagerly need a fast environment to innovate and grow
<@U0548MM6B>: this is something we also say when it comes to issues as the one you just mentioned
some of the provisions might be a burden for data controllers (you guys, dealing with personal data), and especially for small developers

Yeah, that is exactly why DSM is worrying. If an app explodes seemingly overnight and attracts a few million users, it seems like the developer is the one that gets all the blame when something illegal happens.
Like the illegal content uploading for example, it is just not doable to companies that aren’t Google-sized to scan content
^ And even google has trouble keeping up
So if someone uploads a copyrighted song, why should we be the ones punished?
exactly, youtube takes down on DCMA notice

I totally see your points, and we'll make sure to flag this when talking to policy makers. Same thing for platform consultation, when talking about liability of platform we support the idea of maintaining the notice
The European Commission is evaluating all this, there are no new rules so far.

Has it already been an hour? Thanks <@U0DQYPAGZ> for your time and expertise. We can keep the discussion going and try to get everyone's concerns addressed in a post. Slack exists outside space and time...well, time anyway.
Thank you Peter, it has been awesome! Thank you guys, just get in touch with me. It's always great talking to you
Thank you <@U0DQYPAGZ> , cheers!
Thanks <@U0DQYPAGZ> !
Also, please share issues you guys want to address in future discussions. We're thinking encryption given the news this week.

I see a lot of the points as a fight against windmills and those are the old-world political seats in most of Europes countries. Trying to add transparency to insulated structures like Italy is best done by completely exchanging the whole political corpus. Will not happen in this decade... e-gov for every country would be so great, but I am afraid that mobile payment will happen earlier

<@U0F3B7CU9>: It's not just a European problem, it's a global problem. Here in the U.S. pretty much all of our presidential candidates agree it would be a national security disaster if they can't have backdoor access to every major platform.
